pros: Great team to work with.
cons: Floated often to other units.

pros: Pay rate is higher than other per diem
cons: I have no cons right now

job_title: Nursing Student Tech in Akron, OH
pros: As a first job in a hospital setting Summa has taught me so much. I love working on my unit, but on days when I’m floated I don’t mind too much because for the most part the other units are accommodating as well. The pay is great for a tech/aide at $18 days /$19 nights. Plus frequent bonuses available weekly: single bonus extra $25 every 4hr worked…double bonus extra $50 (I believe) every 4h worked…and crisis extra $100 every 4h worker. That’s insane!! If you pick up a 12 hr crisis bonus you’ll make $18/hr PLUS $300. This is as an aide/tech with minimal experience. Great opportunity to make money while in nursing school.
cons: You can be floated to other units which you may not like. Also, you’ll have to take your turn for sitter cases which is sooo brutal when it’s a 12 hour sit. Depending on your unit you could have up to 18 patients which might seem overwhelming (but honestly staff helps…the good nurses answer their own call lights…in this case your main role is BGTs, v/s, call lights). Sometimes I get really mad though when I have this many patients because even though I can fulfill my job, it makes me feel like my patients can be neglected in a way because it’s impossible to answer 5 call lights at once and it’s difficulty to impossible to get everyone cleaned up for the day. However, many patients are independent so, promote autonomy!! Bring them supplies so they can bathe themselves!!

review_title: Good leadership, but understaffed and no room for growth
job_title: Certified Athletic Trainer in Cuyahoga Falls, OH
pros: I liked the people I worked with quite a lot. My schedule was fairly flexible. I also could request to do trainings that were always approved by my supervisor, which was wonderful.
cons: We were short staffed the entire time I was employed there, so we were always doing multiple people's jobs. I tried several times to find positions where I could progress my career but was told I needed an RN to be leadership (despite having a Master's in my healthcare field).

review_title: Literally the worst job I've ever had...and I've worked in barns shoveling manure.
job_title: Patient Access Liason in Cuyahoga Falls, OH
pros: My position allowed me to work from home.
cons: Well, I was ACTUALLY tied to a desk with a 2.5ft cord 10hrs a day with only 10 minutes total of personal time to pee or get some water. Not at all allowed to leave my desk. Calls would drop into our headset one after another and if your calls were too long or if you were wrapping up and documenting in a patient's chart you were penalized. OH, and getting Covid 3 times, while working in Healthcare, it'll get you fired. But first, they force you to get vaccinated. When you're working from home. This place is absolutely the most mismanaged, disorganized, income focused, put on a good face, most unethical, group of trash I've ever met. Patient care is 100% not the focus. The goal is to keep calls (to patients, paging physicians, triaging, refill requests, suicide callers, limited English speakers, etc) under 5 minutes. You get 21 days off a year. But you have to take PTO for all mandatory off holidays. And if you get sick, you get pointed. If your family gets sick, you get pointed. I mentioned my family had Covid 3 times while I worked for Summa, for 12 months. I had to call off a lot but I was willing to pick up hours or even reduce to part time so I could care for myself and family. Further, this year was personally terrible. Close family deaths, broken rib, stage 3 pelvic prolapse, plus a chronic illness that often leaves me bedridden. Taking time off is not at all possible. Every single time I hurt myself, was sick, or my kids were sick, I got SUMMA doctor's notes or was willing to provide my grandma's obituary, for example. I felt so guilty every time I called off, I called my nurse supervisor and took a LIVE COVID TEST just so no one would write me up. You cannot take off work. Nope. Not an option. They pointed me to the point that I had to quit before termination. ......but my patient satisfaction ratings and audits were almost 5 stars or whatever point system they had. I would often take double the calls of my peers in a shift. Further, when I expressed my feelings my job was in danger no team lead, supervisor, manager, or director would help me. I contacted HR and they were also the worst (BTW I have a bachelor's in human resources). No one would help me. The leadership in the Clinical Access Center, with few exceptions, are not worth one single penny. My health was failing and I was forced to go on leave for surgery but thankfully got wind that I was going to be terminated, so I resigned. I could go on and on. When I was hired, they promised I could get on to a 7-3 shift and that was never offered even though when I was hired I was clear on my needs, instead they put on new people for desirable shifts just so they could fill seats. They also promised a $2hr raise at 90 days. That didn't come. And when I voiced that I wasn't being paid for the lunch shifts I worked through, they basically told me to shut up about it if I wanted to keep my job. I have never been so stressed out in my life than when I worked there. I am so relieved to be working for an organization who want to employ people with a good work ethic AND morals.

review_title: Not a bad job but there are pitfalls.
job_title: Environmental Service Aide in Cuyahoga Falls, OH
pros:
Get along with most coworkers
Decent hourly wage
Decent insurance and paid time off, other benefits
Sense of community within hospital despite issues.
cons:
Poor work-life balance, job in EVS is all consuming, 8 hour shifts make it next to impossible to get anything else done during the day.

Heavy workload can be umanageable some days with further assignments being piled on.

"Lower level" workers such as EVS, kitchen staff and CTA's overworked, under appreciated and constantly picked on by other departments.

Drama within EVS department with issues constantly brought up but never dealt with. Fighting between coworkers who are always trying to get out of doing their jobs and playing the "blame game" with each other, other shifts having to pick up the slack which only adds to an already unmanageable workload.

Constant turnover in department.

Point system for tardiness and illness promotes a zero tolerance policy and as a result workers are punished for things that happen beyond their control.

review_title: Pretty good compared to other low- and entry-level jobs, but upper management needs work
pros: good employee benefits, you received your schedule for the whole month instead of just one or two weeks, clear policies, uniforms provided for the EVS staff, understanding and responsive EVS managers, advancement within summa possible
cons: Provided uniforms were oversized men's sizes, so if you are a petite female, they will be too big and you will have to get the pants hemmed. Fear of layoffs. Pay could be better. Upper management caused serious stress for lower management. Tuition assistance is provided, but your manager (at least in my department) is not allowed to adjust your schedule each semester so you can attend class. If you need a specialty class that is only available during one of your workdays, you are SOL. No switching days with another employee allowed. I'm also not too sure about these new policies...

review_title: Poor Moral - Punitive atmosphere-poor staffing ratios-they micromanage and do not promote autonomy - do not encourage in
pros: They usually have very good supervisors on evenings, nights and weekends
cons: Overall, poor management with "bobble head" mentality.  They are not usually proactive of their staff. Any support comes from the Physicians.  I graduated from their school of nursing and have worked with them for most of my career. I used to be jokingly referred to as one of Summa's biggest cheerleaders....unfortunately that is no longer the case. Except for surgical procedures, my family members choose to be treated at other hospitals. Summa has really compromised their ethics and care of patients.  I never thought I would see the day that the Hospital I believed was #1 would fall so low.

review_title: I used to love to come to work!
pros: The floor nurses have your back, they band together to give the best care ever.
cons: There is a disconnect between management and the people who actually provide the care of the patient.  Nurses are put in situations that are unsafe for them and their patient and they hold all of the responsibility against their licenses. They admit patients that they don’t have the staff to care for.

pros:
Got along well with coworkers and boss
Decent hourly wage for the work I was doing (college student)
Time and a half pay when you worked holidays
Paid time off and paid vacation time
Steady, consistent hours, MUCH better than my previous job!
Excellent benefits for even the lowest paid employees
Partial tuition reimbursement depending on your major
cons:
Working 2 holidays a year and one weekend a month
Hard to take classes if you're a working student like I am
I was hired as part time but more often than not worked full time hours due to high turnover rates in my department and short staffing (janitorial staff)
Working around sick people
VERY strict rules about calling off sick, being late, nitpicky staff. Can be quick to reprimand even if circumstances are unavoidable.
Some nights busier than others depending on how many patients are discharged

pros: Easy to be hired into and good for someone who needs employment in a pinch.
cons:
Many. Rules constantly changing and addition of policies health system wide that make it hard for employees to do their jobs, bad management and constant short staffing due to a high turnover rate in all departments, hourly employees seen by management as "replacable", strict attendance policy that does not make any exception for genuine emergencies and easy to rack up points...I could go on and on.

Be prepared to be called in on all of your scheduled days off or asked to stay over into working a 12 hour shift or longer because someone calls off and your department (non nursing) doesn't have the staff to cover, "raises" of .20 or less MAYBE once a year even after you've gained seniority, superbisors and managers who make you feel guilty for not being available/wanting to work all the time and be prepared to be written up at least once within your first six months because of the inflexible attendance system. I am leaving as soon as I can find somewhere else to work.

pros: Some of the hardest working nurses I have met.  It has the potential to be an absolute beautiful facility.  It is in a booming location thanks to University of Akron.  They are expanding and they do amazing work.
cons: The pay is awful.  I can't believe that they cap their nurses out after 6 years.  They understaff horribly.  They wont even let people work overtime when the whole unit is suffering.  At many facilities I've worked at, if they need help then they will offer people double bonus and what not... this facility turn down help.

pros: Interim President is trustworthy and committed to positive change, which is much welcome after an administration built on cronyism, bullying, and micromanagement.
cons: Too many years under the thumb of an inexperienced CEO and influenced by a narcissist in OBGYN that was promoted thanks to million dollar donations from family. Fully responsible for the loss of a well regarded residency education program for the sake of pure greed, which also put the entire hospital's residency programs on probation. Low moral due to micromanaging, job cuts, and overworked staff, which affects patient care. Claims to be dedicated to community health but it's really all about the money.

pros: Quote from Summa's top leaders: be thankful you have a job.
cons: In the last five years, Summa's policies and leadership have taken a decided turn against the employee. The front facing, direct care employees (most impact on the public face of the company) have become expendable, unvalued worker bees. Benefits have been winnowed away until they only exist on paper. Hourly pay has effectively declined, as two 1% raises in eight years does not keep up with inflation. Staff earn vacation, but are afforded no opportunity to use it, only to have it taken away at the end of the year. Further, both clinical and nonclinical policies actively prevent adequate patient care and put my license in jeopardy. Summa as an employer and care delivery entity is a throwback to the industrial revolution: a shining example of why unions were created.

pros: Every person I work with, aside from management, is always very nice, professional, and willing to go out of their way to help others.
cons: Most of the upper management is a joke. Short-staffed most times. Turn-over is very high nowadays. Respiratory therapists are mandated to work overtime whenever management feels like and there definitely aren't enough RRT for the hospital so they are worked to the absolute bone. There are no incentives to go after certifications for your specialty or obtain any sort of higher education. Benefits would be fine for a single person, but they only allow you to see "Summa" healthcare providers. Oh, and if your spouse's job provides healthcare benefits, you won't be able to add him/her to yours.

pros: Summa's working, trying to move in the right direction for healthcare in the current environment. The perspective on population health management and well care is top notch.
cons: While Summa's strategy is top notch and moving in the right direction, there is a significant - almost insurmountable disconnect between the executive team and front line staff.  Implementing an "Optix/Productivity" tool when staffing and process management is below par will ultimately burn out your power employees and create a larger void to long term success.

job_title: Pt Access Representative in Akron, OH
pros: co workers are friendly and helpful
cons: not very understanding when it comes to family emergencies. Expected to do more and more all the time and get punished when you cant complete your work.. no perks like paid holidays. I feel like the boss just wants a butt in the seat. Too many restrictions. The insurance isn't all that either, too many restrictions on that too. Should've done my homework before applying.

review_title: Used to feel like family but layoffs really did their damage
pros: Reasonable pay, good benefits, felt like a safe environment, patients communicated that they felt they were getting good medical care. Shuttle between hospitals for employees was helpful. Free parking a plus.
cons: No raises for over three years; lots of layoffs of absolutely wonderful, hard working employees while those that didn't want to pull their weight kept their jobs. Truly felt as though the rich got richer at Summa.

pros: Great people to work with, makes the night go by fast. You get good experience, not much else than that.
cons: Once you get experience, get out. Patients are pretty much nursing home status and unfit for a rehab facility. All the CEO cares about is filling her wallet, does not care at all about the nursing staff. You constantly work short staffed and the floor begins to sound like an ER because of all the call lights. Upper management does not care about anyone's well being, and do a poor job of pretending that they do. They also treat the Techs like garbage and give them way too many tasks that are impossible to get done. Not to mention tasks that aren't their responsibility, like cleaning rooms (that's for housekeeping to do). The point system is too strict and is always being changed for the worse. If anyone needs to see a gold standard on how to not run a hospital, Summa Rehab is that gold standard.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Akron, OH
pros: The benefits were amazing and the pay was competitive. They had a good routine of holding conferences regarding patient-related safety issues.
cons: Loss of emergency medicine accreditation, loss of streamlined care, staff on 3W neuroscience trauma were VERY CATTY, EAT THEIR YOUNG, GOSSIP 24/7, TALK NEGATIVELY ABOUT THEIR PATIENTS, ALL BREAK AT THE SAME TIME AND LEFT ME TO ATTEND TO THE ENTIRE FLOOR, NEGLECT PATIENTS. Very disappointed in the professionalism and patient satisfaction. Felt as if I was the only RN who took time to form relationships with the patients. Staff walked in and out of rooms to give meds then sat around the nurses station to goof around and expected techs/aids to attend to all the needs of the patients while their IVs ran dry.

pros: All of my coworkers work very hard despite the unpleasant conditions created by management.
cons: A direct quote from the director of nursing sums up the value they place on registered nurses.  This was said during a meeting with employees where there was an open forum to ask questions directly to the director of nursing in regards to eliminating positions.  "The number of nurses does not matter, it doesn't matter how many what-ifs nurses may have eliminated...you are not a billable entity to this company."

pros: Supportive co-workers; organized volunteer opportunities.
cons: Where to begin? I loved being here the first three years; it was a more positive environment than the hospital system I'd come from. Gradually they wore us down. No raises for three years - based on patient ratings, not finances, which isn't fair to administrative employees. Consistently told by management we were lucky to have jobs. In the lowest pay bracket for my job with ten years experience. Very underhanded way of dealing with employees; top management very secretive, with middle managers practically flaunting their "inside" knowledge as to who was next on the chopping block. Poor compensation for employees, and an overpaid administration. One example: Nursing Administrator makes $600,000 a year. No one at Summa contributes enough to the system to earn that much money. How many jobs could be saved by taking back $500K of that?

review_title: The worst company ever to work for
pros: Free drug rep lunches, and drug reps dinners at nice restaurants.
cons: Favoritism, some people don't have to do work if they don't want to, it ends being piled onto the same two people all the time.  People complaining about everything under the sun and never take the to suggest a solution.  Work environment is divided and management is never around when you need her.  They have company rules but only two people in the whole office are expected to follow the rules while others do whatever they want with no consequences.  It's bad, for what they pay the stressful conditions are not worth it.  The new dress codes is outrageous of the rule is employees are not allow to wear their summa t-shirt on summa premises. Too much stuff to mention 😔

review_title: Good but Not as Good as Ratings Suggest.
job_title: Environmental Aide I in Akron, OH
pros: Very reliable steady income, offers several training opportunities for employees free of charge, employee discount programs with some other companies like Dell that could be convenient, reputable company that other employers like to see on your resume.
cons: To advance within the company, there is a hierarchical system for being approved for other positions. If your boss decides they don't like you then your out of luck. There are so many positions you could qualify for but never receive an interview if your manager is not cooperative with HR.

review_title: It was a learning experience, good and not so good.
pros: A few good reason s to work for Summa are 1) ability to work in different jobs and learn new things. 2) ability to grow, during education and job transfer. 3) the multiple shifts/ hours that can be worked.
cons: The fact that they have no leniency on the Flu Vaccination Policy. The fact that they cut the lower wage employees hours, to assist with the budget cuts. How easily they will terminate, over the smallest things. Lastly, their issue with offering unemployment benefits.

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Akron, OH
pros: Great benefits, the Dr’s and Nurses are awesome
cons: Nepotism, favoritism, no paid holidays(have to use your PTO),  intimidation is used to motivate and they make you fear losing your job on a daily basis. They also reward bad behavior by piling more and more work on the employees who work the hardest to compensate for the lazy employees who know that there are no repercussions for them being lazy. Patients are rude and entitled and complain  if you blinked wrong.

pros: Good insurance, flex spending account.
cons: The chain of management literally crumbled and fell the last month I was there. One bad apple made alot of decent MA's leave at the practice I was at. Alot of extra work was piled on top of me for well over a year after they fired another MA, I did her job until i finally quit. Forget about raises at this company. I stuck it out for a few years but finally gave up

review_title: Mangement is Old School and Tone Deaf
pros:
1-3. The organization is committed to providing great healthcare to the local population, and being engaged in the Akron area.
4--6.. Front line employees up through management really care about patient safety and improvising the patient's experience throughout the entire system.
7. The employees who have stuck with Summa through the tough times over the past decade, are good people. 
8. I love that I'm encouraged to develop relationships with my patients and encouraged to advocate for them.
9. I know of an employee who was set up by her supervisor and manger about five years ago.  The employee went through HR, and eventually the legal department was involved. She thought they would just support the management team but once they investigated and discovered the set up, Summa made it right (she got an apology and her job back).
cons:
1. Management style is very old school and unable or unwilling to keep up with the rapid changes in the industry. (building more ERs than community clinics and after hour urgent care centers)
2. System over-site of compliance issues is lax (CMS, Joint Commission have both found real issues that were minimized by management)
3. Employee policies are often ignored when departments short staffed 
4. Senior Management is unable or unwilling to acknowledge and address patient care problems caused by reduced staffing levels. 
5. "DERP" effect - Management ignores events which expose system issues, and attack the messenger instead of taking advantage of the opportunity to address the root cause. (If this review were read by senior management they would be more interested in who wrote this than what is being said).
6. Instead of focusing on the above items, management is rolling out a 1980s era dress code that is horrifying to anyone born after 1985.
7-10. Summa's stagnant wages and benefits are causing an ever widening gulf between Summa and the two major health systems in Cleveland, sucking up some of our best practitioners and staff!

review_title: Lay-offs every budget season and lots of turmoil right now
pros: Pay is probably above average.
cons: CEO just resigned. In may law suits with other hospitals so legal fees are draining the operating funds therefore layoffs to meet bottom line requirements of minority owner.  Convert to software programs before testing is done so the processes are a mess. Being controlled by a minority owner (Mercy) even when results are not best for Summa.

review_title: Ok but has things that can be improved
pros:
Pay is reasonable, stellar medical benefits
Safe working environment
Advancement opportunities
Ability to learn new things on the job and off
cons: Culture on each unit depends on the manager. Sometimes upper management is tone deaf to the workers. Its all about the bottom line and the mighty dollar. Staff feel like they do not count. Gave raises but then took away annual 401K end of year contributions. Really? Staff are not stupid, we can put two and two together to come up with four. That makes you look cheap.

review_title: It no longer feels as welcoming if you are not white.
pros:
Good people who wish to be good employees
Good intentions I think
Patient focus
Wellness program
Moving to ACO, patient outcome focus
cons:
MUCH HAS CHANGED THIS SUMMER
- - This dated and culturally insensitive dress code sends a disturbing message to female and minority employees
- - Management email speaks of projecting a "consistent and professional image" and then goes on to describe Western attire associatd with the white middle and upper classes. Anything else is by deduction, nonprofessional.
- -  American cultural problem of "[rhyms with Lut] Shaming" is reinforced through written policy implying that "bare skin" is unprofessional, requiring employees to be sent home if they are not attired to these mono-cultural standards.
- -Those wearing skirts or dresses are required to wear nylons or "panty hose" which cost several dollars per pair and are very delecate. 
- - Finding hose colored for dark skin is difficult to match and expensive. 
- - Even slacks with sandals are deemed unprofessional if stockings aren't worn with them.
- - Jewish, Muslim, Hindu, Sikh employees are disproportionally impacted by the dress code, which requires them to seek a religious exemption if they wish to wear a hat, head scarf,or dress in non Western attire.
- - Sikh men must ask permission to grow a beard longer than a 1/4 inch. 

I have worked here since I graduated from CWR univerisity in 2008. I never felt awkward or uncomfortable about my race or religion until this summer. Now I feel that I stand out as an odd one. I have to justify my dress, and I'm stared at by other Summa employees and patients and their families. My coworkers are wonderful people but it is still uncomfortable to be in the public spaces. I wonder if I should wear a style of Hijab that is more obviously religious than my of head scarf, but the style I wear is significant to me.

I feel sad and frustrated. I spoke to a person in HR who was sympathetic but what could she do? I will most likely move to a more accepting hospital system, rather than feeling like I have to justify my attire and defend my religion.

My religion prevents me from getting a tattoo, but I do not think that a hospital system should refuse to hire a person who has a sleave tattoo or other large ink where covering it would be difficult or risk contamination from bandages. Employees should be judged on their ability to connect with and treat our patients, and support each other not on how we look. My patients remember me because I connect with them. My religion and my birth country are less to them than my attention and foucs.

review_title: PROFESSIONAL AND MAGNETISM AT ITS BEST
pros: Summa ACH is a quality patient centered facility that provides the most recent and up-to-date evidence based practice. The are committed to their employees by offering educational and professional advancement.
cons: Like many health care facilities Summa must deal with a shortage of nursing and ancillary staff.

pros:
Great place to get some Nutrition experience especially if you've just started out
Pretty reasonable PTO with time and a half as well as overtime. Pretty flexible schedulimg.
cons: You work ever other weekend and holiday. Not many opportunities for upward movement. When I tell family members how much I make the look at me with great concern as the can't believe someone with a degree is making that little. However that's a problem with all diet tech jobs across Ohio

pros: Summa Health System is an excellent place to work. It has consistenetly been honored with awards for being a Top Employer in Northeast Ohio and lives up to the promise.  Employees are committed to providing high qualit, compassionate and safe healthcare to our patients.
cons: Summa is a large employer with many locations and sub groups. As a result it can be difficult for employees to stay informed about all of the changes and growth at the orgainzation.  In order to feel connected the employee must make an effort to be informed by reading and attending learning opportunities.

pros:
Coworkers are helpful 
Most managers are supporting
cons:
Overload staff
All of the honest people that made positive contributions to this company have been laid off and were not able enough time to take home all belongings before leaving, had to return for your personal stuff and were treated impersonally. 
 Company only cares about making money not your well being , it’s not a hospital it’s a business.  
The CEO is not aware of how the culture really is day in and day out. 
Staff  who were rude to patients were never held accountable for their actions and are still working and have a job. People who have been there for long time get away with anything.

pros:
* Good Health Benefits
* Working in Healthcare you are up to date on the area
* Management and upper management was helpful and pleasant to work for even though the culture and scope of the company is negative.
cons:
*Toxic environment
*Constant uncertainty if your job will be eliminated or not
*Negative vibe around the culture and how the company is going. Everyone feels like it is constantly going down
*Each company meeting is about how poorly the company is doing
*Employees constantly leaving and stating how the company is not a long term solution

pros: Decent pay, can write my own schedule, fair holiday scheduling, awesome boss, helpful co-workers, and payroll deduct available for the cafeteria, health insurance, union, 401k
cons: Some rude doctors, outdated computer system (which is changing soon anyway), old dusty work environment, a few too many people with an "I don't care" attitude, very limited health insurance options, and it seems like a lot of services provided are being moved to the city campus

pros: Used to be a great place to work prior to buy out my alternate health solutions. I thought the pay was fair at around $32 hourly with 7 years exp as RN.
cons: They gave very little notice of the company being bought out and changing pay, pto, benefits, job/hours. The new pay per visit basically pays an RN $24 an hour. I know this because I did the job for 6 years.

review_title: If you want to work for these imbeciles, go right ahead
job_title: Medical Laboratory Technician in Akron, OH
pros: Great facility, community and coworkers. I made many friends and loved my job. I had zero problems with management or the facility.
cons: Well, it was a fantastic place to work until they closed down inpatient services. I was "let go" and not given the courtesy of a phone call, email, or assistance finding another job. I found out on my own while trying to log into the employee portal from home. I was told that they were NOT obligated to inform me of my position being eliminated because I was a PRN employee. It has been YEARS since this happened and I am still REPULSED.

pros: ..... Some of the people that work there do truly care. They have recent renovations and a decent cafeteria. That's about the only positives I can think of.
cons: Management is unaware of what is really happening. Patient care and privacy is compromised daily. Employees are treated as numbers and not individuals. They have a high, medium and low rating system, but being rated high means nothing. There is no compensation or promotion for being a high performer. No incentives.

job_title: Protective Services Service Officer in Akron, OH
pros: There are none. Don't work here.
cons: Horrible place to work. They treat their employees like work mules and pay dirt. Registration staff makes more than commissioned police officers that work for summa. Protective services dept command staff have no respect for the officers under them and don't care at all. An officer can see a crime being committed and will be told to let it go because they don't want a their police department to be too aggressive. This place is a joke. I make 12.54/hr. I'm a commissioned peace officer.

pros: Easily accessible from most locations.
cons: Salary and staffing could be better. Parking is inadequate, but they are working on it.

pros: Good people....excellent benefits....I never plan on leaving....really plan on retiring from there.
cons: Could use some adjustments in the area of being late for work....there are things that happen that may be out of your control and therefore this area should be looked at.

pros: Nice people, love my coworkers.  Great benefits, love the time off and the ability to carry over time from year to year.  Good starting wage
cons: Distance from parking to office.  Limited places to use insurance benefits.  The fact that you can't cash in you PTO at full pay.

pros: A paycheck...but my soul is not for sale
cons: HR, Dress Code, Wages, Hours, Management, Favortisim, Benefits

pros: I have been with Summa for over 28 years in the Respiratory Department.  Summa has gone through and weathered many changes in leadership even within the department, but the leadership team continues to treat everyone fairly and remain consistent.  There are always opportunities if you want them to expand your knowledge and work in other areas within Respiratory Care.
cons: Can't think of anything that would be a con.  Summa is a great place to work.

review_title: Do not recommend long term employment
job_title: Patient Access Liaison III in Akron, OH
pros: Rapid hiring process, easy access to HR policy
cons: Management culture, time and attendance system, compensation scale, potential for position advancement, job position transferring, comparable compensation to area standards, employee support, work/life balance

pros: Certain management, but HR is beyond excellent and ensure employers obey their rules and regulations. After my one and only incident involving HR, I had a wonderful experience as an employee at Summa. Everyone is very kind, feels like a second home.
cons: The only place I have worked where I had to involve HR.

review_title: This was a very rewarding experience. It has prepared me for the medical field. It has led me to further my education.
pros: The ability to help patients was very rewarding. The team work of the staff made the patients feel comfortable and let them know they were in good hands.
cons: The only con was while working in the Oncology Department, was seeing patients lose the battle of fighting their disease

pros: Working with co workers and good smart people
cons:
Pay is not close to being competitive. 

Hospital expanding a new building with not enough employees to staff it.  Not fair to current employees.

Many people quit and leave, summa does not make it very enticing to make employees want to stay with company.

If you enjoy being under staffed and under paid this is the place for you.

pros: good co workers and big company that is fair with employees and consistent with salary and amount of time you have been a RN
cons: need a 4 year degree to advance due to magna status, does not count with years of being a nurse.

pros: I enjoy working on my floor because it concentrates on team nursing. Everyone is extremely helpful all of the time.
cons: We have been dealing with a lot of low staffing. If that was taken care of, I think it would be a wonderful place to work.

pros: The people that we work with are amazing. We do try to help patients. Benefits are pretty good. Could be better
cons: The whole system runs off fear of losing job. They pile more and more on you and tell you to be thankful you have a job. Training is a bit scarce.

pros: Great insurance, shift differential for nights, great training and orientation, free continuing education credits, $2500/year education reinburstment (untaxed on paycheck), ymca gym membership discount, nice PTO earnings, 4013B with matching at 6% after 1 year.  Pay is exceptionally higher than other hospitals in the area. Typically 2-4$ higher an hour.  Yearly raises.
cons: Short staffing is the only con I can think of

review_title: Obsolete software development and incompetent management
pros:
3 weeks of PTO
Good health insurance
Centrally located in Akron near freeways
cons:
Very high-stress environment due to bad processes and entrenched employees.
"Good 'ol boy network" in full force. New employees are expected to serve those with seniority regardless of experience or ability. Extreme incompetence in business analysis and project management due to poor quality employees. Software development managers are non-technical and responsible for a hostile work environment. 
Very unfriendly, unhappy co-workers who never want to hang out after work and won't even give you a ride if your car breaks down. 
Too many uneducated or low-performing employees working in technical positions, and promoted based on seniority rather than ability. 
Managers are former business analysts who know the healthcare system but not software development. Salaries all over the place.
The development department has no methodologies or rhyme or reason for doing things--they just react. They do nothing but respond to program aborts every morning because the source code is a mess, written by questionable programmers, and nothing is ever done to clean it up and improve it for the long term. Instead, aborts are handled day by day with endless bandaids. 
New employees are blamed for failures, entrenched employees are given a free pass over and over again. 
If you confront an entrenched employee who has the ear of a manager, prepare to be given the boot as soon as the opportunity arises.
Program updates moved into production without ANY testing. No QA department! Despite the fact that software breaks continuously and people are relying on their claims to be processed and ID cards to be printed. Nothing is ever done, just more bandaids. Deep wounds are never treated.

pros: Very good people to work with that are extremely committed to patient care. Flexible schedules and great benefits. They also offer education assistance.
cons: Short staffed, Poor on giving raises. They have a pretty stiff point system. Do not pay for employees holidays.

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Medina, OH
pros:
Decent benefits. 
The CEO is trying new methods to better the healthcare experience.
cons:
Lowest pay rates in hospitals in NE Ohio.
The goal is to get patients in and out as quickly as possible, whether they are satisfied or not. 
Departments get cut often, which increases workload without pay raise.

pros: There is good commradere between fellow co-workers. Opportunity for personal and professional development exist. Pay was adequate, benefits were fair.
cons: No raises in over four years. In a contraction mode right now due to changes in reimbursement. Tends to overextend itself and then panic at the cost of employee careers.

job_title: Environmental Service Aide in Akron, OH
pros:
*move at your own pace
*good entry level position in hospital environment
cons:
*management disorganized 
* too much gossip

review_title: Worst Place I have ever worked.
pros: There are no "Pros." There is so much dead wood currently there that getting anything done is impossible.
cons:
Tons of "racial cards" sexual harassment, 
Example, sleep with me or your fired. Try to discipline someone for using the Lords name in vein and the individual who spoke these words gets away and the person who was offend gets fired.

pros: Large system, benefits, decent medical coverage, dental & vision available. Many lateral moves available at multiple campuses . Good location to major interstates. Local YMCA discounts
cons: Little professional encouragement for advancement there. Too much focus on esthetics and surface issues. Example: what the cafe sells and what employees wear prior to clocking in for work.

job_title: Research Billing Compliance in Akron, OH
pros:
Largest employer in county
Flexibility in area I am in
cons:
Financials with changes in healthcare - limited raises or room for advancement
Room for advancement limited in area of knowledge
Too many silos that do not integrate
Not enough resources provided to do our jobs

review_title: As a temporary employee  it is sometimes hard to fit in
pros: flexible so that I do not have to work 5 days a week but temporary work takes some personality that is resilient
cons: As a sub you have to be ready to go at the drop of a hat and do whatever is asked

pros: Great team, fun and rewarding job, interesting work!  I thoroughly enjoy my job, and I learn a lot every shift!
cons: Variable schedule, working nights, weekends and holidays.  Limited autonomy and room for growth as an NP or PA.  Work with different people all the time -- difficult to get to know each attending physician's preferences.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in East Dubuque, IL
pros: because you have know one to order you around and also i like working with people and i love what i was doing my supervisor were great also.
cons: i do not like to do other people jobs when they are there.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oxon Hill, MD
pros: Because i can motivated and i have good communication skills and i and helping person and if someone has a problem i will be happy to help with no complaining
cons: I have no cons because i willing to do whatever to get this job i can work mu way up to the top

review_title: Pretty decent employer and could be a nice place to work
job_title: Patient Access Representative in Akron, OH
pros: make pretty good pay and hours.
cons: Too strict. Managers don't mind mandating you in a hearbeat and I don't like to accomodate people for vacations at all. Very strict.

pros: Coworkers are great and neighboring departments great to work with.
cons: Senior management has is ideas and heads in the wrong places. HR is not supportive unless they are pushed. No pay increase in 4 years, always promised and never delivered. Reason, unexpected expenditures.

review_title: Social Worker II OB and Women's Health
job_title: Medical Social Worker II in Akron, OH
pros: It is a great environment to learn, because it is a teaching hospital. You need to like working in teams, as the interdisciplinary team in the medical setting is important.
cons: Medical work can be stressful and fast paced. You need to be flexible and able to work in different conditions.

pros: Great coworkers, diverse culture, decent benefits
cons: Uninformed management, Unable to progress within Summa unless you are an RN, extremely poor employee morale

review_title: Not a bad place to get your foot in the door
job_title: Laboratory Support Associate in Akron, OH
pros:
Benefits
Almost always a chance for overtime
cons:
Impersonal
Critical
Uncaring
Unwilling to understand when family emergencies occur

pros: Great benefits, most employees are great and really care about the patient.
cons: Bad company's financial decisions/management causing overworked, over stressed employees due to low, low staff levels.

pros: Balanced work/life schedule. Fostered healthy work environment with fellow coworkers.
cons: Benefits need to be more challenging for a hospital.  Raises are handed out inconsistently. An example is regional hospitals receive raise but not entire organization.

pros: The learning experiences are numerous throughout many different areas.
cons: The office management is not on site at my current employer and it is not easy to reach management regarding a situation that needs to be handled immediately.

pros: Prior to partnering with CHP SUMMA was an employer that valued employees.
cons: Since Catholic Health Partners have been in charge it's been nothing but cuts in staff and in employee benefits. Very embarrassing top management decisions. Loss of Certification to have a Residency program. Totally the fault of greedy upper management decisions. The CEO has resigned but that will solve nothing.

job_title: Quality Technician HIM in Akron, OH
pros: Good company, competitive benefits, nice professional start for medical records worker.
cons: Management may not always be fair. Growth potential is possible but slow.

pros: Pros have been eclipsed by cons in recent years.
cons: Company employee relations philosophy is "ask not what Summa can do for the employee, but what the employee can do for Summa." Policies disallow employees from actually using benefits; no functional raise in 6 years (the two small raises were offset by benefit cuts, resulting in a net loss for the employee). Etc.

pros: The coworkers are wonderful to work for. They're able to be flexible with scheduling. There is room to grow.
cons: Many times their hands are tied and they are short staffed too often.

review_title: Summa does pretty well, but should continue to work harder
pros: Very easy commute, good benefits, family friendly
cons: Long hours, salary competitiveness, lack of management opportunities

pros: Insurance is ok but should be better for a healthcare system; my manager is great and has an open-door policy
cons: Tiny raises when there is one; insurance isn't what it should be for a healthcare system

pros: Lunch breaks & clocking out. The main pro will be leaving this sinking ship! Dictatorship doesn’t equal leadership! There’s a reason why this place isn’t the top employer anymore
cons: This organization treats their employees like prisoners or kids in a daycare. No trust or respect. You get what you give. Poor leadership with a constant turnover. Don’t waste your time applying here. Go to ACH or CCAG.

pros: The people I worked with were great for the most part.  I miss the patients and I give props to all the ICU nurses.
cons: Your voice as an employee is not heard by management, at least from my experience.

pros: Fairly good benefits.  Some good colleagues. Many nice patients.
cons:
Poor management
Blaming culture
Rude and unprofessional treatment of employees by management
Mistrust of management by employees
No opportunities for advancement
Serious problem with favoritism
Favored employees can treat patients and colleagues unprofessionally and not suffer consequences
Consistent notice of errors, no acknowledgement of good work.  Very disheartening.
No raises

pros: great teamwork and floor staff.  Supervisors are great.
cons: Upper management does not care about what is happening on the floor.  Will let you work extremely short on night shift and they do not come in to help

job_title: Emergency Department RN in Akron, OH
pros: Most coworkers get along well
cons: mgmt. plays favorites, high turnover

review_title: Wonderful experience... if you work at main campus.
pros: great benefits...good pay. lots of room for advancement.
cons: management is living in a dream world... most clinical areas are largely understaffed.

review_title: Human resources is terrible and don't inform employees of resources
pros: Hours were great for a family
cons: Close minded , little training , and no help from human resources when facing challenges

review_title: I loved being the first person a patient seen
pros: Its a great company, that you can advance within
cons: I don't have any downsides besides I need part time employment at this moment

review_title: Patient care is not top priority here!
job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Wadsworth, OH
